Regular train and bus services connect South Queensferry with Edinburgh city centre. First Scotrail
train services run from Waverley (2 services per hour) and Haymarket (4 services per hour) stations to Dalmeny station which is a short (10min) walk from the town centre.

value: service no. 43 operates from Waterloo Place via Princes Street with 4 services per hour.

service no. 747 operates from Edinburgh Airport to Inverkeithing with a stop at the south end of the Forth Road Bridge serving South Queensferry. Services 53 (Edinburgh - Dalgety Bay), 55 (Edinburgh -
- Dunfermline/Dalgety Bay) also stop at the south end of the bridge.

South Queensferry is located next to the main A90
motorway. The A904 is the main road from
South Queensferry is only 3 miles/5 km from Edinburgh International Airport

value: The first sight that most visitors to South Queensferry have is of the bridges that cross the Firth of Forth between South Queensferry and North Queensferry
content=was completed in 1890 and forms part of the East Coast Mainline railway from
content= was completed in 1964 and opened by Queen Elizabeth II.
content=A new road bridge under construction and expected to be complete in 2016. A small exhibition is open on summer Saturdays.

Other sights within South Queensferry include the historic High Street which includes houses dating from the 15th Century; St Mary's Episcopal Church dating from 1441 and the Hawes Inn, made famous by Robert Louis Stevenson's novel 'Kidnapped'.
South Queensferry is bordered by three stately homes.
name=Port Edgar Marina and Sailing School
content=Dinghy saliing, Kayaking/canoeing, powerboating. Hire and tuition available at this council-run facility. Berthing facilities available for visiting yachts.

content=A traditional New Years Day swim in the "refreshing" waters of the Firth of Forth. "Dook" is a lowland Scots word meaning dunk. If you're feeling fuzzy-headed after the Hogmanay festivities this will certainly clear it.
content=Annual festival held in August in which the entire community participates enthusiastically. Perhaps the strangest aspect is the

procession, where a local man is covered from head to toe in burrs (the sticky hooked fruit of the burdock) and then leads a procession throughout the town's streets. As his odd garb restricts the Burry Man's movements the procession is a slow one taking several hours, so he is accompanied by 2 assistants who fortify him with nips of whisky through a straw.
address=17 The High Street, South Queensferry

content=Restaurant, bar and boutique hotel, right on the waterfront in the centre of South Queensferry. Three levels of outside decking for those sunny days - with great views of the Firth of Forth and the bridges.

content=With views overlooking the sea, this is a place to go to impress a special someone. With a luxurious decor but without any pretences, The Boathouse delivers tasty delights with seafood featuring prominently on the menu.
address=Seals Craig Hotel Edinburgh Road, South Queensferry
content=Attentive staff cater to your needs at this charming Italian restaurant.
content=Character-laden old pub with good real ales and pub grub. Nautical memorabilia and occasional live music.
content=With a heated outdoor area, Moorings is the place to relax and enjoy a drink in both summer and winter. They serve roast dinners every Sunday from 1 - 4PM.
directions=Pretty much under the Rail bridge, at the eastern end of the seafront

content=Historic Inn, where the 19th Century novelist Robert Louis Stevenson is said to have stayed whenever he was journeying to and from the north of the country. The inn is mentioned in his celebrated novel
content=One of the first of an emerging chain by the man behind the Malmaison and Hotel du Vin groups. Has already gathered numerous plaudits.
hours=Mon and Weds 1PM-8PM; Tues, Thu & Fri 10AM-5PM; Sat 9AM-5PM
